2017-04-10.abstract: France’s most famous conceptual artist might finally be getting the attention she deserves — in America.
2017-04-10.snippet: France’s most famous conceptual artist might finally be getting the attention she deserves — in America.
2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: IT’S POURING WHEN the taxi leaves me in front of Sophie Calle’s building in Malakoff, a working-class suburb 10 minutes from Paris. At first I question the address: The building — gray and nondescript — is as dreary as the day. It’s not the home you’d expect for a conceptual artist whose work can be uncommonly frisky. But inside, there’s a leafy courtyard ringed by ateliers, one of which is blazing with light. I spot the artist through her studio’s floor-to-ceiling windows. She meets me at the door looking classic kooky-sexy Calle: low-cut black cocktail dress, elaborately crocheted black tights, massive tinted glasses and sheepskin slippers.
2017-04-10.headline_main: The Fertile Mind of Sophie Calle

2017-04-10.abstract: The chef Jenn Louis’s “The Book of Greens” focuses on leafy greens and rare vegetables.
2017-04-10.snippet: The chef Jenn Louis’s “The Book of Greens” focuses on leafy greens and rare vegetables.
2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: Do not expect new ideas for asparagus or haricots verts if you pick up “The Book of Greens” by Jenn Louis, a chef and restaurateur from Portland, Ore. This beautifully photographed book is tightly focused on edible leafy plants, some of which, like arugula and romaine, you’ll encounter every day. Many others, including chrysanthemum greens and red orach, are rarities in most markets, though her recipes suggest substitutes. Ms. Louis’s tastes are influenced by her travels to Asia, with dishes like chard paneer and shu mai with collard greens. A section on herbs bypasses tarragon and chervil in favor of curry leaf and pandan. Recipes for Manila clams with sorrel and cream, and charred cabbage with miso and lime, are keepers. There is a useful grouping of greens according to taste, texture, seasonality and style of preparation: “The Book of Greens: A Cook’s Compendium” by Jenn Louis with Kathleen Squires (Ten Speed Press, $35).
2017-04-10.headline_main: New Cooking Ideas for Everyday Greens and Rarities

2017-04-10.abstract: Jurors in Manhattan were swayed by an insider trading narrative against William T. Walters, even with a “morally corrupt” witness for the prosecution.
2017-04-10.snippet: Jurors in Manhattan were swayed by an insider trading narrative against William T. Walters, even with a “morally corrupt” witness for the prosecution.

2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: The blue corn tostada served at Atla, the Mexican-inspired restaurant that Enrique Olvera just opened in NoHo, is a bright purple slab that sits atop a bowl of ayocote-bean hummus. Mr. Olvera and Daniela Soto-Innes created this fried tortilla, which resembles, in look only, the oversize baked Oaxacan chip called a tlayuda. Beans and tahini are puréed with ancho chile, avocado leaves and onions for the dip, and the tostada makes digging into the hummus irresistible and fun: White ayocote hummus, $14, Atla, 372 Lafayette Street (Great Jones Street), atlanyc.com.
2017-04-10.headline_main: At Atla, One Chip Big Enough for the Whole Bowl

2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, women have publicly lodged sexual harassment complaints against the Fox News host Bill O’Reilly. In 2004, a producer on his show, Andrea Mackris, filed a lawsuit accusing him of harassing her with sexually explicit phone calls. Tabloids and late-night TV hosts seized on the lurid details, which included telling her to buy a vibrator, calling her while apparently masturbating and engaging in one-sided phone sex entailing loofas — some of which Ms. Mackris said she recorded.
2017-04-10.headline_main: In Sexual Harassment Cases, What Are We Settling For?

2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: “He’s a former Sandinista. He had all these ponchos and sailor tops, and these ginormous bell-bottoms,” says the Los Angeles-based knitwear designer, Maria Dora. She’s talking about her father — who emigrated from Nicaragua before meeting her mother, who was born in the Phillipines and raised in Germany. They met as med students in San Francisco. “My mother was very prim,” Dora says, laughing. “Ruffles were the furthest she went.”
2017-04-10.headline_main: Designer to Know: Bringing Back ’70s Style With Knits

2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: The photographer Larry Fink has never thought much of Andy Warhol. “His art was interesting as phenomena, but not terribly deep,” he says. “But what’s interesting is Warhol’s commodification of all things — and he was a hustla, and a reasonably cruel hustla, at that,” Fink pounds in his Brooklyn accent. “You know, Warhol became a bit more generous in his later years and his foundation does good work, so I’m not absolutely negative on Andy, but he wasn’t my favorite dude. Let’s put it that way.”
2017-04-10.headline_main: Andy Warhol, in the Context of His Time

In the 31 years since the release of his debut album, “Guitar Town,” he’s published a short-story collection and a novel, run a theater company and acted on television in “The Wire” and “Treme.” In his spare moments, he hosts the weekly “Hardcore Troubadour Radio” show on SiriusXM and an annual songwriting camp in the Catskills.

2017-04-10.abstract: This multimedia production examines the people and backstage dramas that went into the making of “Casablanca” in 1942.
2017-04-10.snippet: This multimedia production examines the people and backstage dramas that went into the making of “Casablanca” in 1942.
2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: It takes audacity to recreate the circumstances behind a movie whose stature is sacred. “CasablancaBox” — a production at Here, a downtown locus of experimental theater — is a brave, almost foolhardy undertaking, presenting the backstage drama during the making of “Casablanca,” and daring its audience to compare its cast members to the actors in what many believe to be the finest Hollywood movie of all time. And it delves into the factors that informed a classic: World War II geopolitics, a hothouse studio-system environment, assorted colorful personal histories and a series of happy accidents.
2017-04-10.headline_main: Review: ‘CasablancaBox’ Is Looking at You, Kid, Behind the Scenes

2017-04-10.abstract: Maia proves to be a character with no moral center or desires of her own.
2017-04-10.snippet: Maia proves to be a character with no moral center or desires of her own.
2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: Memory is unreliable. It is colored by emotions, shaped by biology and underscored by morality. The memories you carry aren’t so much unvarnished facts as they are the truth you believe in. The fact that memory is so mutable isn’t always a problem. But it becomes one for Maia on this week’s episode of “The Good Fight,” as she learns quite painfully that her unreliable memory and lack of self-preservation are damning qualities.
2017-04-10.headline_main: ‘The Good Fight’ Season 1, Episode 9: Blinding Privilege

2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Jia Jinglong, a villager in northern China, was executed late last year for killing an official he blamed for the demolition of his home, the news media boiled with debate about the death sentence. Mr. Jia’s family and lawyers argued that the official had victimized him and that his life should have been spared.

2017-04-10.lead_paragraph: As soon as the tears started to come, Paulo Dybala buried his face into his jersey. Lionel Messi tried to offer an arm around the shoulder as he trudged, bereft, from the field; so, too, did Angel Di Maria. For a few seconds, the defender Emmanuel Mas stopped Dybala in his tracks, swaddling him in a tender, consoling hug.

The cabinet declared that a state of emergency was in effect. A newspaper was pulled off newsstands after it criticized the government.

2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — Congressional Republicans knew next year’s election could prove difficult, as the first midterm campaigns for the party controlling the White House often are. But not until a few days ago would they have believed that their immediate challenge would be hanging onto a House seat they have controlled for over two decades, in a district that President Trump carried by 27 points and that just happens to be home to that most nefarious of liberal boogeyman: Koch Industries.

2017-04-11.abstract: So much of what is worthwhile requires us to choose discomfort.
2017-04-11.snippet: So much of what is worthwhile requires us to choose discomfort.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: I do not generally read sports memoirs in search of life wisdom. I turn to them for silly nicknames and disgusting locker-room pranks and inscrutable jargon-laden accounts of on-field action. All of which treasures are to be found, in great abundance, in the new memoir by the former Atlanta Braves third-baseman Chipper Jones. For instance: the pitcher Greg Maddux (nickname: Doggie) not only had a magical ability to change his fastball grip to a changeup mid-delivery but also enjoyed pranking teammates in the shower by spontaneously urinating on them.
2017-04-11.headline_main: New Sentences: From ‘Ballplayer,’ by Chipper Jones

2017-04-11.abstract: People from nutrition geeks to philosophers are using a metaphor from software to describe the world.
2017-04-11.snippet: People from nutrition geeks to philosophers are using a metaphor from software to describe the world.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: In 1990, when computers were still merely in the process of taking over the world, John Daugman, a computer scientist and researcher at Harvard University, published an article titled “Brain Metaphor and Brain Theory,” noting a habit he had observed among his peers. “Invariably,” he wrote, “the explanatory metaphors of a given era incorporate the devices and the spectacles of the day.” In other words: We describe everything as if it were technology. The metaphors we use to talk about brains and minds struck Daugman as especially susceptible. The technology that Greeks and Romans developed for pumping water, for instance, underpinned their theories of the four humors and the pneumatic soul. Later, during the Enlightenment, clockwork mechanisms left their imprint on materialist arguments that man was only a sophisticated machine. And as of 1990, it was concepts from computing that explained us to ourselves: “Today’s embrace of the computational metaphor in the cognitive and neural sciences is so widespread and automatic that it begins to appear less like an innovative leap than like a bandwagon phenomenon,” he wrote. “There is a tendency to rephrase every assertion about mind or brains in computational terms.”
2017-04-11.headline_main: New Technology Is Built on a ‘Stack.’ Is That the Best Way to Understand Everything Else, Too?

2017-04-11.abstract: In a period of global uncertainty, some Japanese photographers offer new ways of seeing.
2017-04-11.snippet: In a period of global uncertainty, some Japanese photographers offer new ways of seeing.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: In an essay titled “Late-Night Thoughts on Listening to Mahler’s Ninth Symphony,” the physician and essayist Lewis Thomas wrote: “I cannot listen to the last movement of the Mahler Ninth without the door-smashing intrusion of a huge new thought: death everywhere, the dying of everything, the end of humanity.” The essay was published in Thomas’s 1983 book of the same title, and he was talking about the likelihood of nuclear apocalypse. When I first read it in the mid-’90s, I appreciated its mournful lyricism, even as it felt like a time capsule of the worries of a different generation.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Pictures in the Aftermath

2017-04-11.abstract: A historian of conservatism looks back at how he and his peers failed to anticipate the rise of the president.
2017-04-11.snippet: A historian of conservatism looks back at how he and his peers failed to anticipate the rise of the president.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: Until Nov. 8, 2016, historians of American politics shared a rough consensus about the rise of modern American conservatism. It told a respectable tale. By the end of World War II, the story goes, conservatives had become a scattered and obscure remnant, vanquished by the New Deal and the apparent reality that, as the critic Lionel Trilling wrote in 1950, liberalism was “not only the dominant but even the sole intellectual tradition.”
2017-04-11.headline_main: I Thought I Understood the American Right. Trump Proved Me Wrong.

Inside, Joseph Baivatu, 29, prepares to make the next payment on a layaway for something very special: a large sperm whale tooth. Known as a tabua in Fiji, a sperm whale’s tooth is often given by a groom and his family to the parents of the man’s (hopefully) future bride when he asks permission to marry her.

2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Reacting to worries and conjecture spreading in South Korea of a possible pre-emptive American military strike on nuclear-armed North Korea, the government sought to reassure citizens on Tuesday that there would be no such attack without its consent.

2017-04-11.abstract: Reporter Sarah Lyall writes about Sergey Ponomarev’s approach to the photos for the Times series on London which begins today with an essay by Ms. Lyall.
2017-04-11.snippet: Reporter Sarah Lyall writes about Sergey Ponomarev’s approach to the photos for the Times series on London which begins today with an essay by Ms. Lyall.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: It’s one thing to take the measure of a place after having lived there for a long time and knowing it well; it’s another to do so on your second visit. Sergey Ponomarev, a Moscow-based photographer who has done extensive work for The New York Times, has a great deal of experience in the Middle East, where he has long covered various conflicts (he recently received a Robert Capa gold medal for his work in Iraq). When David Furst, The Times’s international picture editor, asked him to photograph London for a new series on the city’s fate post-Brexit, Mr. Ponomarev, 36, had only been there once.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Moving Pictures: Sergey Ponomarev’s Slow Look at London

2017-04-11.abstract: Highlights from the worlds of fashion, food and art.
2017-04-11.snippet: Highlights from the worlds of fashion, food and art.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: Just before the Rei Kawakubo exhibition opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute next month, Barneys New York will unveil its own tribute to the designer with a window installation pairing archival Comme des Garçons looks with the sculptures of the late Louise Bourgeois. Viewed alongside each other, the works reveal a striking coherence of form. Take Bourgeois’s “Echo I,” a sweatshirt turned inside out, stretched vertically from sleeve to sleeve and cast in bronze, next to a drapey Kawakubo knit wool dress with elongated sleeves bundled at the wrists. The works also share a preoccupation with psychology and the passing of time. For Bourgeois, clothes were tokens of the past, a place she often returned to; accompanying the installation will be a recording of Bourgeois, in her 90s, singing songs from her girlhood. Meanwhile, Dennis Freedman, the former Barneys creative director who conceived of the project, talks of the profundity of watching the Comme des Garçons fall 2015 show: “They narrowed the runway so the models had to turn and face each other before going their separate ways,” he says. “One fashion writer quoted Dickens, saying ‘Life is made of ever so many partings welded together.’” — KATE GUADAGNINO
2017-04-11.headline_main: Just 6 Things: News and Trends to Know About

2017-04-11.abstract: Mr. Spicer, the White House spokesman, apologized after incorrectly stating, in a criticism of the Syrian president, that Hitler had not used chemical weapons.
2017-04-11.snippet: Mr. Spicer, the White House spokesman, apologized after incorrectly stating, in a criticism of the Syrian president, that Hitler had not used chemical weapons.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House press secretary, Sean Spicer, set off an intense backlash on Tuesday when he suggested that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria was guilty of acts worse than Hitler and asserted that Hitler had not used chemical weapons, ignoring the use of gas chambers at concentration camps during the Holocaust. Mr. Spicer later apologized.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Sean Spicer Raises Outcry With Talk of Hitler, Assad and Poison Gas

2017-04-11.abstract: A hypnotic, female spirit permeates two works: Adrienne Truscott’s “THIS” (“I know, you’re all like — this is a dance?”) and Lily Gold’s “Good Mud.”
2017-04-11.snippet: A hypnotic, female spirit permeates two works: Adrienne Truscott’s “THIS” (“I know, you’re all like — this is a dance?”) and Lily Gold’s “Good Mud.”

2017-04-11.abstract: The latest from the team behind Café China, plans for Hudson Yards, and other restaurant news.
2017-04-11.snippet: The latest from the team behind Café China, plans for Hudson Yards, and other restaurant news.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: YELLOW MAGNOLIA CAFÉ This restaurant at Brooklyn Botanic Garden has been built into a stretch of sunny, polished greenhouse and features a mural of yellow magnolias, a flower first developed at the garden. It’s a wing of the majestic Palm House, a glass-and-steel structure designed by McKim, Mead & White, dedicated in 1917 as the Conservatory, and used for catered events. The architect David Rockwell has very subtly updated the interiors of both and added a bridal suite to the Palm House. Both are run by Patina Restaurant Group, which has restaurants in a number of public venues. The food is under the direction of Rob Newton, the chef and restaurateur who owns Nightingale Nine and Wilma Jean in Brooklyn. “The food needs to be clean and light, with lots of vegetables,” he said. His seasonal menu includes spring vegetable crudités, several salads, chicken with ramp dumplings and fiddleheads, and fish tacos with cilantro and radishes: Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 990 Washington Avenue (Eastern Parkway), Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, 718-307-7136, yellowmagnoliacafe.com.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Yellow Magnolia Café Opens at Brooklyn Botanic Garden

2017-04-11.abstract: The company, whose season at the Joyce begins on April 18, has become less easy to define, as its vision of the Spanish-speaking world has grown more fluid.
2017-04-11.snippet: The company, whose season at the Joyce begins on April 18, has become less easy to define, as its vision of the Spanish-speaking world has grown more fluid.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: What does it mean to run a Latino dance company in New York in 2017? For many Americans, Latin dance still means mambo or salsa or Mexican folk dancing — in other words a mixture of social dance and folklore. Sassy moves, tight skirts, perhaps a ruffle or two.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Ballet Hispánico Dances the ‘Identity Mambo’

2017-04-11.abstract: Thousands of New York Times readers reacted to an article about a United Airlines passenger who was forcibly removed from a flight.
2017-04-11.snippet: Thousands of New York Times readers reacted to an article about a United Airlines passenger who was forcibly removed from a flight.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: Cellphone videos of an unidentified man being dragged off a United Airlines flight on Sunday elicited outrage after passengers posted the videos on Twitter. The footage shows the man screaming as he was forced out of his seat by a security officer and dragged down the aisle by his arms. There was blood visible on his mouth, and his glasses and shirt were askew.
2017-04-11.headline_main: ‘Everyone Has a Price’: Readers React to Removal of Passenger From United Flight

2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a shiny, glass-and-metal shopping mall appeared in Lower Manhattan, the kind of thing Manhattan natives (your stopgap Critical Shopper included) longed for in their foolish youths when suburban friends would floss and brag. It is called Brookfield Place, and behind its streak-free panes wait Diane von Furstenberg and J. Crew, Burberry and Bottega Veneta, a Lululemon and a designer gym to wear it in.

2017-04-11.snippet: With prosecutors and police officers in control, expect more wrongful convictions.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: Prosecutors applauded the April 10 announcement by Attorney General Jeff Sessions that the Department of Justice was disbanding the nonpartisan National Commission on Forensic Science and returning forensic science to law enforcement control. In the same statement, Mr. Sessions suspended the department’s review of closed cases for inaccurate or unsupported statements by forensic analysts, which regularly occur in fields as diverse as firearm and handwriting identification, and hair, fiber, shoe, bite mark and tire tread matching, and even fingerprinting analysis.

2017-04-11.abstract: A railroad worker dutifully turns in the cash he finds strewn across on the tracks but soon comes to regret it in this incisive, funny Bulgarian film.
2017-04-11.snippet: A railroad worker dutifully turns in the cash he finds strewn across on the tracks but soon comes to regret it in this incisive, funny Bulgarian film.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: It’s always been difficult to be an honest, moral person in a corrupt world, and as “Glory,” a new movie from Bulgaria, demonstrates, it’s also increasingly ridiculous. Directed by Kristina Grozeva and Petar Valchanov from a script they wrote with Decho Taralezhkov, “Glory” opens on a typically colorless morning (we infer) for Tzanko, a bushy-haired state-railroad employee portrayed by Stefan Denolyubov. His extravagant beard will immediately register as the kind that is not a hipster accouterment.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Review: The ‘Glory’ of a Good Deed (and Its Fallout)

2017-04-11.abstract: A passenger is yanked from his seat, and that’s only one of the indignities of air travel.
2017-04-11.snippet: A passenger is yanked from his seat, and that’s only one of the indignities of air travel.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: Flying was once an adventure, more than just a way to get from here to there. But over the years, it has become something to dread. You wait in endless lines for the chance to be poked, patted, X-rayed, interrogated, generally insulted and, in the final indignity, separated by class as you, at last, board. And it can get worse from there. On Sunday security officials at Chicago’s O’Hare airport literally yanked a passenger off a United flight because the airline needed seats for its staff.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Fear of Flying, for Good Reason

2017-04-11.abstract: Whether 157 pending applications in 36 countries risk violating the Constitution is an open question, as no president has tested the limits like Donald J. Trump.
2017-04-11.snippet: Whether 157 pending applications in 36 countries risk violating the Constitution is an open question, as no president has tested the limits like Donald J. Trump.
2017-04-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For most of last year, Donald J. Trump’s application to register trademarks for his brand of home accessories languished in a government office in Lima, Peru. But since Mr. Trump was elected in November, the pace has picked up.
2017-04-11.headline_main: Trump’s Trademark Continues Its March Across the Globe, Raising Eyebrows

2017-04-12.abstract: When Robert Bentley became Alabama’s governor, evangelical Christians hoped he would be a model of integrity. On Monday, he resigned after a sex scandal.
2017-04-12.snippet: When Robert Bentley became Alabama’s governor, evangelical Christians hoped he would be a model of integrity. On Monday, he resigned after a sex scandal.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — As governor, Robert Bentley would quote the Bible before the Alabama Legislature and say that God had elevated him to the State Capitol. In his dermatology practice, in the city where he was a Baptist deacon, he sometimes witnessed to patients. And when he was a first-time candidate for statewide office, his campaign headquarters were often filled with volunteers from local churches.
2017-04-12.headline_main: For Alabama Christians, Governor Bentley’s Downfall Is a Bitter Blow

2017-04-12.abstract: In Syria, Nigeria and elsewhere, President Trump has inherited international crises where intervention efforts are likely to have only modest success.
2017-04-12.snippet: In Syria, Nigeria and elsewhere, President Trump has inherited international crises where intervention efforts are likely to have only modest success.

2017-04-12.abstract: Paola Clemente, 49, died in 2015 of a heart attack at a vineyard. An investigation found female laborers were routinely exploited and their pay skimmed.
2017-04-12.snippet: Paola Clemente, 49, died in 2015 of a heart attack at a vineyard. An investigation found female laborers were routinely exploited and their pay skimmed.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: SAN GIORGIO IONICO, Italy — Her husband can still recall how Paola Clemente used to set two alarms to make sure she woke in the middle of the night — 1:50 a.m. — to catch the private bus that would take her and dozens of other women to the vineyards.
2017-04-12.headline_main: A Woman’s Death Sorting Grapes Exposes Italy’s ‘Slavery’

2017-04-12.abstract: The buzz is about the revival of the MiMo Historic District, which is filling up with stylish shops, restaurants, bars and boutique hotels.
2017-04-12.snippet: The buzz is about the revival of the MiMo Historic District, which is filling up with stylish shops, restaurants, bars and boutique hotels.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: The buzz in Miami these days is about the revival of the MiMo Historic District, which is filling up with stylish shops, restaurants, bars and boutique hotels. Encompassing 27 blocks along Biscayne Boulevard, the stretch was vibrant in the 1950s but fell into disrepair, with its once family-friendly motels renting rooms by the hour. Today MiMo, which stands for Miami Modern, bears more semblance to its glory days; longtime residents as well as newcomers, motivated by comparatively affordable rents, have set up shop and are behind MiMo’s renewed energy.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Five Places to Go in Miami

2017-04-12.abstract: The Justice Department shut down a commission that was examining the use of techniques that have helped falsely convict people.
2017-04-12.snippet: The Justice Department shut down a commission that was examining the use of techniques that have helped falsely convict people.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: A tooth expert came to a Staten Island court in 1998 and said the teeth in James O’Donnell’s mouth proved he had bitten a woman who had been sexually assaulted in Clove Lakes Park. Another such expert testified in upstate New York that Roy Brown’s teeth were “entirely consistent” with the bite marks found all over the body of a woman who was killed in 1991 outside a farmhouse near Auburn. Both men went to prison. Both were proved innocent later through DNA testing.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Another Reprieve for Expert Testimony That Is Anything But

2017-04-12.abstract: Mike Hamersky, a lawyer from Queens, said the Knicks were impeding his efforts to renew his season tickets after he yelled at James L. Dolan to sell the franchise.
2017-04-12.snippet: Mike Hamersky, a lawyer from Queens, said the Knicks were impeding his efforts to renew his season tickets after he yelled at James L. Dolan to sell the franchise.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Mike Hamersky, the Knicks fan who got into an altercation with James L. Dolan, the team’s owner, outside Madison Square Garden last week, now says he is having trouble renewing his season tickets.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Knicks Fan Involved in Spat With Dolan Says He Can’t Renew Tickets

2017-04-12.abstract: Despite convictions of the Legislature’s leaders, New York lawmakers ignored many of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposals. “It was all rhetoric and no action,” an observer said.
2017-04-12.snippet: Despite convictions of the Legislature’s leaders, New York lawmakers ignored many of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s proposals. “It was all rhetoric and no action,” an observer said.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: On the day that the state budget deadline came and went without an agreement in Albany, Preet Bharara, the recently dismissed United States attorney in Manhattan, dispatched a cheeky post on Twitter: “#BREAKING Bold, sweeping, principled ethics reforms finally enacted in New York State! The swamp, drained. #AprilFools.”
2017-04-12.headline_main: On Ethics, Cuomo Budget Entered Like a Lion and Emerged Like a Lamb

2017-04-12.abstract: Mr. Lacey won convictions against mayors, other public officials and Mafia members before becoming a judge whose cases included the French Connection trial.
2017-04-12.snippet: Mr. Lacey won convictions against mayors, other public officials and Mafia members before becoming a judge whose cases included the French Connection trial.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Frederick B. Lacey, a police chief’s son who as a tenacious federal prosecutor helped drain New Jersey’s fetid swamp of political corruption and who later built a reputation as a stringent judge presiding over celebrated cases, died on April 1 in Naples, Fla. He was 96.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Frederick B. Lacey, Who Prosecuted Corruption in New Jersey, Dies at 96

2017-04-12.abstract: Emily Carroll returns with an offer to pay her way.
2017-04-12.snippet: Emily Carroll returns with an offer to pay her way.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — When we last saw Emily Carroll, she was making her New York Times Crossword debut with a flavorful puzzle designed to tickle the taste buds. Today, Ms. Carroll is subtly sending us a bill for that meal.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Go Dutch

2017-04-12.abstract: The ruling by a judge on Brazil’s Supreme Court allows prosecutors to start new inquiries of at least eight ministers in Mr. Temer’s cabinet and much of the senate.
2017-04-12.snippet: The ruling by a judge on Brazil’s Supreme Court allows prosecutors to start new inquiries of at least eight ministers in Mr. Temer’s cabinet and much of the senate.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A judge on Brazil’s Supreme Court authorized new corruption investigations on Tuesday involving dozens of the country’s most powerful politicians, dealing yet another blow to the beleaguered government of President Michel Temer.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Michel Temer Government in Brazil Reels as Dozens Face New Graft Investigations

2017-04-12.abstract: Mr. Estes defeated James Thompson, the Democratic candidate, in the first national test of Republicans’ electoral strength and a contest that saw a late infusion of national support from Republicans.
2017-04-12.snippet: Mr. Estes defeated James Thompson, the Democratic candidate, in the first national test of Republicans’ electoral strength and a contest that saw a late infusion of national support from Republicans.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: WICHITA, Kan. — Ron Estes, the Republican candidate for an empty House seat in Kansas, survived a surprisingly competitive race in a heavily conservative district on Tuesday. He defeated James Thompson, the Democratic candidate, in the first national test of the Republican Party’s electoral strength, in a contest that saw a late infusion of national support from Republicans nervous about the tumultuous political environment during President Trump’s initial months in office.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Ron Estes, a Republican, Survives Tight House Race to Win Kansas Seat

2017-04-12.abstract: “Centerfold,” “Freeze-Frame” and “Love Stinks” were among the band’s most popular songs.
2017-04-12.snippet: “Centerfold,” “Freeze-Frame” and “Love Stinks” were among the band’s most popular songs.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: J. Geils, the guitarist who lent his name to the J. Geils Band, which in the early 1980s produced a string of catchy pop hits, including “Love Stinks,” “Freeze-Frame” and “Centerfold,” was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Groton, Mass. He was 71.
2017-04-12.headline_main: J. Geils, Whose Band’s Catchy Pop Hits Colored the 1980s, Dies at 71

2017-04-12.abstract: Elizabeth and Philip bid someone a sad farewell and learn some troubling news about the past.
2017-04-12.snippet: Elizabeth and Philip bid someone a sad farewell and learn some troubling news about the past.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: The best characters in “The Americans” keep leaving for the Soviet Union: Martha, Oleg and now — after Tuesday night’s somber, moving episode, “Crossbreed” — Gabriel. Would it be too much to hope that they’re setting up a Moscow-based, post-Soviet spinoff? “The Russians”?
2017-04-12.headline_main: ‘The Americans’ Season 5, Episode 6 Recap: ‘I’m Going Home’

2017-04-12.abstract: The new guidance is the next step in fulfilling President Trump’s ambition to reshape the federal bureaucracy into a lean, businesslike operation.
2017-04-12.snippet: The new guidance is the next step in fulfilling President Trump’s ambition to reshape the federal bureaucracy into a lean, businesslike operation.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration on Wednesday will lift the hiring freeze that it had imposed on the federal work force, even as it directs agencies to submit plans for personnel cuts and other restructuring moves to fit the budget blueprint released by President Trump last month.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Trump’s Directive Will Lift Hiring Freeze, as It Asks Agencies for Cuts

2017-04-12.abstract: Cespedes had a chance to join an elite club: Only 16 players have hit four in a game. Lucas Duda added two homers for the Mets, and Asdrubal Cabrera and Travis d’Arnaud had one each.
2017-04-12.snippet: Cespedes had a chance to join an elite club: Only 16 players have hit four in a game. Lucas Duda added two homers for the Mets, and Asdrubal Cabrera and Travis d’Arnaud had one each.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — In the seventh and eighth innings against the Phillies on Tuesday night, Yoenis Cespedes threatened to add his name to an exclusive page in baseball’s history books. Four-home-run games are exceedingly rare — a feat even harder to achieve than throwing a perfect game. There have been 23 of those, but only 16 four-homer games.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Yoenis Cespedes Hits Three Homers as Mets Rout the Phillies

2017-04-12.abstract: Will it have robots? No checkout counters? Virtual fitting rooms? Almost anything seems possible.
2017-04-12.snippet: Will it have robots? No checkout counters? Virtual fitting rooms? Almost anything seems possible.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: LONDON — What will the store of the future look like? Will we be served by fleets of gleaming robots, using built-in facial recognition technology to adjust each sales pitch to a person’s current mood or past spending preferences? Will there be voice-activated personal assistants, downloading the availability, color and fit of any and every garment to your smartphone? Three-D printing stations? No checkout counters when you leave? Could there even be floating, holographic product displays on the shop floor that change when a customer walks by?
2017-04-12.headline_main: Imagining the Retail Store of the Future

2017-04-12.abstract: A whirlwind tour of the drinks scene in the Czech Republic’s second city.
2017-04-12.snippet: A whirlwind tour of the drinks scene in the Czech Republic’s second city.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: By the time I tasted my squid-ink old-fashioned — made with Japanese whiskey and served alongside a wakame-and-sesame salad — I had to admit something cool was happening in Brno.
2017-04-12.headline_main: In Brno, Drinks for Morning, Noon and Night

2017-04-12.abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
2017-04-12.snippet: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Good morning.
2017-04-12.headline_main: United Airlines, Borussia Dortmund, Sean Spicer: Your Wednesday Briefing

2017-04-12.abstract: Kansas’ Fourth Congressional District shifted 24 points toward Democrats in Tuesday’s special election.
2017-04-12.snippet: Kansas’ Fourth Congressional District shifted 24 points toward Democrats in Tuesday’s special election.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Kansas’ Fourth Congressional District shifted 24 points toward Democrats in Tuesday’s special election.
2017-04-12.headline_main: The Republican Won, but Voters Shifted Left in the Kansas Special Election

2017-04-12.abstract: “Toni Erdmann,” Maren Ade’s deliriously silly Oscar nominee, arrives on streaming platforms. And don’t miss Aisha Hinds as Harriet Tubman on “Underground.”
2017-04-12.snippet: “Toni Erdmann,” Maren Ade’s deliriously silly Oscar nominee, arrives on streaming platforms. And don’t miss Aisha Hinds as Harriet Tubman on “Underground.”
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: “Toni Erdmann,” Maren Ade’s deliriously silly Oscar nominee, arrives on streaming platforms, along with her practically perfect earlier film, “Everyone Else.” And don’t miss Aisha Hinds’s tour de force as Harriet Tubman on “Underground.”
2017-04-12.headline_main: What’s on TV Wednesday: ‘Toni Erdmann’ and ‘Underground’

2017-04-12.abstract: A surprisingly close seven-point victory in a deep-red district suggests that the G.O.P. is heading for trouble in 2018.
2017-04-12.snippet: A surprisingly close seven-point victory in a deep-red district suggests that the G.O.P. is heading for trouble in 2018.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: This season’s special congressional elections are being heralded as a test of whether newly energized Democrats will fare better with an unpopular Republican president.
2017-04-12.headline_main: A Republican Wins in Kansas. It’s Still a Loss for the G.O.P.

2017-04-12.abstract: Two exhibits opening this month showcase the work of Todd Webb, who arrived in New York in 1945 with a view camera and an insatiable curiosity.
2017-04-12.snippet: Two exhibits opening this month showcase the work of Todd Webb, who arrived in New York in 1945 with a view camera and an insatiable curiosity.

2017-04-12.headline_main: Vintage Photos of What Made Postwar New York City Tick

2017-04-12.abstract: Identifying myself as disabled never felt right. A friendship with Oliver Sacks helped me understand why.
2017-04-12.snippet: Identifying myself as disabled never felt right. A friendship with Oliver Sacks helped me understand why.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Not long ago I had an experience that most authors wish for. Someone recommended my book.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Seeing Outside the Disability Box

2017-04-12.abstract: The real turning point in the judicial wars happened in 1990.
2017-04-12.snippet: The real turning point in the judicial wars happened in 1990.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: The death of the judicial filibuster last week was overshadowed by Syrian airstrikes and White House turmoil, but the moment’s significance was also diminished by its inevitability. Senators made pious noises and partisans bemoaned the state of the republic, but the widespread Washington wisdom was that this was a fait accompli: After decades of “Butter Battle Book”-style escalations in the judicial wars, a minority veto was simply too antiquated, anachronistic and pre-ideological to survive.
2017-04-12.headline_main: David Souter Killed the Filibuster

2017-04-12.abstract: President Trump could fill as many as five of the Federal Reserve’s seven seats. Politics must be kept out of the nomination process.
2017-04-12.snippet: President Trump could fill as many as five of the Federal Reserve’s seven seats. Politics must be kept out of the nomination process.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: I was in the room when President Bill Clinton decided to reappoint Alan Greenspan, a lifelong Republican originally appointed by Ronald Reagan, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. A political adviser urged Mr. Clinton to choose an administration ally, but that was never seriously considered. The president’s choice was not determined by party, or politics or ideology.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Don’t Politicize the Federal Reserve

2017-04-12.abstract: Revoking a few bonuses is just a start. The bank must do a lot more to restore trust.
2017-04-12.snippet: Revoking a few bonuses is just a start. The bank must do a lot more to restore trust.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: In its latest attempt to salvage the reputation of Wells Fargo, the bank’s board announced on Monday that it would revoke $75 million in bonus awards from two former senior executives who it said were largely to blame for a staggering sales scandal at the bank.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Plenty More Villains at Wells Fargo

2017-04-12.abstract: A strategy built on territory won’t ultimately eliminate the terrorist group.
2017-04-12.snippet: A strategy built on territory won’t ultimately eliminate the terrorist group.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: The Trump foreign policy team has been all over the map on what to do next in Syria — topple the regime, intensify aid to rebels, respond to any new attacks on innocent civilians. But when pressed, there is one idea everyone on the team seems to agree on: “The defeat of ISIS,” as Secretary of State Rex Tillerson put it.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Why Is Trump Fighting ISIS in Syria?

2017-04-12.abstract: In the hour of his country’s grief, the prime minister said Swedes would not let their fundamental values be undermined by hatred.
2017-04-12.snippet: In the hour of his country’s grief, the prime minister said Swedes would not let their fundamental values be undermined by hatred.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Each terrorist attack tests anew the values of openness and tolerance essential to free societies. Stockholm became the scene of another such attack  on Friday when a barreling truck was turned, yet again, into a deadly weapon. This time four were killed and 15 were injured.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Sweden’s Wisdom on Terrorism

2017-04-12.abstract: His 1967 visit helped change how America saw deprivation. But not enough.
2017-04-12.snippet: His 1967 visit helped change how America saw deprivation. But not enough.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: OXFORD, MISS. — The toddler had no time for this white man in a fine dark suit. Robert Kennedy may have been a former attorney general and the brother of a slain president, but Annie White’s son was focused on the cornbread crumbs scattered on the floor of his dilapidated home in Cleveland, Miss.
2017-04-12.headline_main: What Mississippi Taught Bobby Kennedy About Poverty

2017-04-12.abstract: A prominent Chinese state-run newspaper warned the North that it faced a cutoff of vital oil supplies if it dared test a nuclear weapon.
2017-04-12.snippet: A prominent Chinese state-run newspaper warned the North that it faced a cutoff of vital oil supplies if it dared test a nuclear weapon.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s leader, Xi Jinping, and President Trump spoke by phone on Wednesday about the escalating tensions with North Korea as a prominent Chinese state-run newspaper warned the North that it faced a cutoff of vital oil supplies if it dared test a nuclear weapon.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Xi and Trump Discuss Rising Tensions With North Korea

2017-04-12.abstract: Two exhibits opening this month showcase the work of Todd Webb, who arrived in New York in 1945 with a view camera and an insatiable curiosity.
2017-04-12.snippet: Two exhibits opening this month showcase the work of Todd Webb, who arrived in New York in 1945 with a view camera and an insatiable curiosity.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: By the time Todd Webb arrived in New York City in 1945, he’d lived enough lives for several men. He had lost his fortune in the 1929 crash; hunted for gold in California, Mexico and Panama; worked for Chrysler in his hometown, Detroit; and served in the South Pacific as a photographer’s mate first class. But it was in New York City that his love of photography took off, albeit with a slight detour.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Vintage Photos of What Made Postwar New York City Tick

2017-04-12.abstract: Forget left vs. right. This presidential campaign is about populism vs. liberalism.
2017-04-12.snippet: Forget left vs. right. This presidential campaign is about populism vs. liberalism.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: PARIS — For the first time in the history of the last three French republics, the two front-runners in the presidential election deny belonging to the right or the left, or even the center, of the political spectrum.
2017-04-12.headline_main: France’s Neither-Nor Election

2017-04-12.abstract: The effort to replace Antony Burgmans is the latest flare-up in a dispute over whether the Dutch paint and chemicals company should engage in merger talks.
2017-04-12.snippet: The effort to replace Antony Burgmans is the latest flare-up in a dispute over whether the Dutch paint and chemicals company should engage in merger talks.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The hedge fund Elliott Management said on Wednesday that it would seek to replace the chairman of Akzo Nobel, the Dutch paint and chemicals company, in an increasingly acrimonious fight over whether the company should discuss a takeover with its American rival, PPG Industries.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Elliott Management Seeks to Remove Akzo Nobel Chairman

2017-04-12.abstract: With the number of older people on the rise in China, longevity-themed tourism is blossoming. Take a 360 tour of Bama County, where visitors breathe in the air that is said to have healing powers.
2017-04-12.snippet: With the number of older people on the rise in China, longevity-themed tourism is blossoming. Take a 360 tour of Bama County, where visitors breathe in the air that is said to have healing powers.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: With the number of older people on the rise in China, longevity-themed tourism is blossoming. Take a 360 tour of Bama County, where visitors breathe in the air that is said to have healing powers.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Is This China’s Fountain of Youth?

2017-04-12.abstract: United Airlines had the wrong person hauled away, said the host of “Jimmy Kimmel Live!”
2017-04-12.snippet: United Airlines had the wrong person hauled away, said the host of “Jimmy Kimmel Live!”
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Jimmy Kimmel Wants United to Drag Donald Trump Off the Plane

2017-04-12.abstract: Most complaints against imitations depend on a hard nature-versus-art distinction, one that never really holds up.
2017-04-12.snippet: Most complaints against imitations depend on a hard nature-versus-art distinction, one that never really holds up.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: When I profess my affection for fake flowers, I often feel as though I’m confessing a character flaw. They have, to say the least, a bad reputation. As decoration, they are considered tacky; as gifts, tactless. They are widely regarded as creepy and depressing — the association is with the debauched fakeries you’ll find on the lapels of birthday-party clowns and the sad sacks of nylon collecting dust in the waiting rooms of our laziest dentists.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Letter of Recommendation: Fake Flowers

2017-04-12.abstract: Four years after her debut album, the pop prodigy is back with a testimonial to heartbreak and solitude.
2017-04-12.snippet: Four years after her debut album, the pop prodigy is back with a testimonial to heartbreak and solitude.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Lorde, the New Zealand-born pop star, came into the fire-lit lounge of her downtown Manhattan hotel a few minutes past 11, apologizing for the lateness of the hour — funny story, she said. She’d been commuting daily to a Greenwich Village recording studio, plugging away at new music, but today U2, who had reserved the space, arrived and commandeered it. Lorde found a smaller studio available farther uptown, and though the move was inconvenient, she saw the humor in being inadvertently evicted by Bono — it was just one more marker of how strange her life has been since she became famous, four years ago, at 16. “I actually saw the Edge in the gym here,” she said with a grin. “I thought about saying something, but I decided, Nahhh.”
2017-04-12.headline_main: The Return of Lorde

2017-04-12.abstract: Some examples of what the administration can do to major provisions of the Affordable Care Act.
2017-04-12.snippet: Some examples of what the administration can do to major provisions of the Affordable Care Act.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Some examples of what the administration can do to major provisions of the Affordable Care Act.
2017-04-12.headline_main: What Trump Can Do Without Congress to Dismantle Obamacare

2017-04-12.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on cognitive disability and the nature of consent, and what an employee owes to an employer.
2017-04-12.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on cognitive disability and the nature of consent, and what an employee owes to an employer.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: My sister suffered a brain injury two years ago that left her with severe short-term memory loss. She has made a very good recovery, but she still requires full-time supervision and cannot work. On a typical day, she wakes up unable to remember how old she is, what city she lives in or what she did the previous day. Thankfully, she has retained most of her original personality; however, she is very easily confused, and her maturity level is similar to when she was a teenager.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Is It O.K. to Marry an Amnesiac?

2017-04-12.abstract: The Museum of the American Revolution, opening on April 19, features artifacts, digital recreations and a historic tent (Washington slept here).
2017-04-12.snippet: The Museum of the American Revolution, opening on April 19, features artifacts, digital recreations and a historic tent (Washington slept here).
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: In Philadelphia’s new Museum of the American Revolution, a tableau of five life-size figures depicts a brawl between a diverse group of men who have come to Boston in the winter of 1775-76 to join the rebellion against the British government.
2017-04-12.headline_main: In Philadelphia, the American Revolution Gets a Museum

2017-04-12.abstract: The process for new construction is arduous, no one wants the jails in their backyard, and the mayor doesn’t want the fight as he gears up for a re-election campaign.
2017-04-12.snippet: The process for new construction is arduous, no one wants the jails in their backyard, and the mayor doesn’t want the fight as he gears up for a re-election campaign.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Before making his promise to replace Rikers Island with jails elsewhere in the city, Mayor Bill de Blasio was adamant about one thing: He would commit to the goal, but say nothing about precisely where any new jail should go.
2017-04-12.headline_main: De Blasio Faces Tough Road Replacing Rikers With New Jails

2017-04-12.abstract: President Trump selected Kevin Hassett, who believes that immigration spurs economic growth, to lead his Council of Economic Advisers.
2017-04-12.snippet: President Trump selected Kevin Hassett, who believes that immigration spurs economic growth, to lead his Council of Economic Advisers.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The choice by President Trump of a pro-immigration economist to lead his Council of Economic Advisers is stirring a backlash among his most ardent supporters, who worry it is an abandonment of the tough stance he took on the issue during the campaign and the latest in a string of broken promises.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Choice of Pro-Immigration Economic Adviser Riles Trump’s Base

2017-04-12.abstract: In a statement, Rob Manfred was said to have expressed a desire “to transition away from the Chief Wahoo logo,” a smiling caricature the team uses that many find offensive.
2017-04-12.snippet: In a statement, Rob Manfred was said to have expressed a desire “to transition away from the Chief Wahoo logo,” a smiling caricature the team uses that many find offensive.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Cleveland Indians returned home to Progressive Field on Tuesday for the first time since an agonizing Game 7 defeat to the Chicago Cubs in the World Series. They raised the 2016 American League pennant and handed out rings before the focus turned back to the current season.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Commissioner Starts to Press Cleveland Indians About Logo

2017-04-12.abstract: The city has transformed itself into a vibrant cultural and artistic hub, though traces of its Rust Belt roots remain.
2017-04-12.snippet: The city has transformed itself into a vibrant cultural and artistic hub, though traces of its Rust Belt roots remain.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Of all the things to love about Pittsburgh, its bridges are perhaps the most visible. There are over 440 bridges, an astounding number for a city of 300,000 people — hence its nickname City of Bridges. I was standing on the Roberto Clemente Bridge, named after the great Pirates outfielder, looking up the Allegheny River at two other huge, majestic steel bridges: the Andy Warhol and the Rachel Carson. The three pale-mustard-color suspension bridges, known as the Three Sisters, are part of a system without which Pittsburgh, which meets at the convergence of the Allegheny, Monongahela and Ohio Rivers, would be a fractured collection of neighborhoods.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Built on Steel, Pittsburgh Now Thrives on Culture

2017-04-12.abstract: Silicon Valley prides itself on its capacity to upend entrenched industries. But airlines have eluded tech disruption.
2017-04-12.snippet: Silicon Valley prides itself on its capacity to upend entrenched industries. But airlines have eluded tech disruption.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: There are many reasons for the sorry state of commercial aviation in America. When it comes to your routinely terrible flight — not to mention the sort of exceptional horror that took place aboard United Airlines Flight 3411 last weekend — regulatory failures as well as consolidation, which the authorities have allowed to occur unabated for decades, can be blamed.
2017-04-12.headline_main: How Technology Has Failed to Improve Your Airline Experience

2017-04-12.abstract: Shonda Rhimes of “Scandal” and the people behind “Veep,” “Madam Secretary” and “House of Cards” talk about reality bumping into fiction.
2017-04-12.snippet: Shonda Rhimes of “Scandal” and the people behind “Veep,” “Madam Secretary” and “House of Cards” talk about reality bumping into fiction.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It’s got to be one of the best jobs in Hollywood: Sit around all day dreaming up fantasy political scenarios that are either so over-the-top crazy or wishfully idealistic — plotlines that could never play out in real life — that they provide the sort of escapist television viewers crave.
2017-04-12.headline_main: How to Write TV in the Age of Trump: Showrunners Reveal All

2017-04-12.abstract: A roundup of new young adult fiction includes stories of a thief seeking justice, a skeleton revealing a city’s shameful past and a gorilla spinning tales.
2017-04-12.snippet: A roundup of new young adult fiction includes stories of a thief seeking justice, a skeleton revealing a city’s shameful past and a gorilla spinning tales.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: BANG By Barry Lyga 295 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $17.99. (Young adult; ages 12 and up)
2017-04-12.headline_main: New Y.A. Novels Tackle Crime and Its Consequences

2017-04-12.abstract: Visitors hoping to cure their ailments or simply have a longer life head to Bama County, in southern China, which is known as the country’s “longevity capital.”
2017-04-12.snippet: Visitors hoping to cure their ailments or simply have a longer life head to Bama County, in southern China, which is known as the country’s “longevity capital.”
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: BAMA COUNTY, China — His legs numb from a stroke, his head throbbing with pain, Wu Weiying came to the jagged green mountains of southern China in search of a cure.
2017-04-12.headline_main: China’s Aged and Sick Flock to a Hamlet Known for Longevity

2017-04-12.abstract: A suburb with urban conveniences easy to reach on foot, and home to generations of families.
2017-04-12.snippet: A suburb with urban conveniences easy to reach on foot, and home to generations of families.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: A suburb with urban conveniences easy to reach on foot, and home to generations of families.

2017-04-12.abstract: A suburb with urban conveniences easy to reach on foot, and home to generations of families.
2017-04-12.snippet: A suburb with urban conveniences easy to reach on foot, and home to generations of families.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Dina Santillo-Ortiz and her husband, Ray Ortiz, had yearned for a larger home in an affordable community with good schools and a reasonable commute. But they were hesitant to leave their old Jersey City neighborhood and its many conveniences.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Nutley, N.J.: A Place to Land and to Stick Around In

2017-04-12.abstract: The annual festival at Brooklyn Botanic Garden takes place at the end of April — regardless of when nature decides to push play.

2017-04-12.abstract: Runners tended to live about three more years than nonrunners, even if they run slowly or sporadically and smoke, drink or are overweight.
2017-04-12.snippet: Runners tended to live about three more years than nonrunners, even if they run slowly or sporadically and smoke, drink or are overweight.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Running may be the single most effective exercise to increase life expectancy, according to a new review and analysis of past research about exercise and premature death. The new study found that, compared to nonrunners, runners tended to live about three additional years, even if they run slowly or sporadically and smoke, drink or are overweight. No other form of exercise that researchers looked at showed comparable impacts on life span.
2017-04-12.headline_main: An Hour of Running May Add 7 Hours to Your Life

2017-04-12.snippet: It looks like Sisi’s real concern is solidifying his authoritarian rule, not cracking down on jihadists who kill Egyptians.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: The Islamic State’s affiliate in Egypt is on the march. On Palm Sunday, a pair of bombs killed 45 people at church. This was the third major attack on Coptic churches in less than four months — and the first such attack recently in major Egyptian cities, which many people believed were more secure. These attacks follow after months of terrorism, and they could have been predicted: Just two months ago, the Sinai-based Islamic State affiliate issued a video promising that the group would target Copts in Egypt’s mainland.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Does Egypt’s President Really Want to Fight Terrorism?

2017-04-12.abstract: Being obese, smoking or having high cholesterol, hypertension or diabetes in midlife is associated with brain changes of Alzheimer’s years later.
2017-04-12.snippet: Being obese, smoking or having high cholesterol, hypertension or diabetes in midlife is associated with brain changes of Alzheimer’s years later.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Being obese, smoking or having high cholesterol, high blood pressure or diabetes in midlife is associated with an increased risk of dementia later in life. Now researchers have found these five risk factors correlate with the development, years later, of amyloid brain plaques, a hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Heart Risks in Midlife Tied to Brain Plaques of Alzheimer’s

2017-04-12.abstract: The painter Robert Ryman is giving 21 of his works, a mini-survey of his career, to Dia. The paintings will remain in rooms of their own, as arranged by the artist.
2017-04-12.snippet: The painter Robert Ryman is giving 21 of his works, a mini-survey of his career, to Dia. The paintings will remain in rooms of their own, as arranged by the artist.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Robert Ryman, one of the most revered artists of his generation, takes painting to places where the air is thin and the view can be vertiginous. “It helps to think of Mr. Ryman as a kind of philosopher-carpenter, with an inborn, almost mystical love of paint as paint,” Roberta Smith wrote in 2015 in The New York Times. “‘Is this a painting?’ ‘Is that a painting?’ could be taken as the main credo of his art. He doesn’t always provide easy answers.”
2017-04-12.headline_main: Robert Ryman, Minimalist Master, Donates Trove to Dia Art Foundation

2017-04-12.abstract: Ms. Winfrey, the star of the HBO film adaptation, talks about the book’s resonance and her reluctant decision to be in the movie.
2017-04-12.snippet: Ms. Winfrey, the star of the HBO film adaptation, talks about the book’s resonance and her reluctant decision to be in the movie.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Rebecca Skloot’s “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks” was a publishing and scientific sensation earlier this decade that spent 75 weeks on the New York Times paperback nonfiction best-seller list. The book told the story of an African-American woman named Henrietta Lacks whose “immortal” cell line, known as HeLa, came from her cervical cancer cells in 1951. Ms. Skloot, as both narrator and author, traced the afterlife of these cells: HeLa emerged as one of the most widely used lines in medical research and helped establish the multibillion-dollar vaccine industry, cancer treatment and in vitro fertilization industry. This was all done without the knowledge of, consent from or any compensation paid to Lacks’s family as it struggled with racism and poverty in Baltimore.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Oprah Winfrey on ‘The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks’

2017-04-12.abstract: The candidate’s statement about Vel d’Hiv in World War II should dispel any illusions about her.
2017-04-12.snippet: The candidate’s statement about Vel d’Hiv in World War II should dispel any illusions about her.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Marine Le Pen showed the world that she is, after all, her father’s daughter when she said France was not responsible for rounding up Jews during World War II to be sent to German concentration camps. Ms. Le Pen worked hard in recent years to cleanse her far-right National Front party of the virulent anti-Semitism — spouted by her father and other party leaders — that made it unpalatable for decades for all but hardened bigots on the political fringes.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Marine Le Pen’s Denial of French Guilt

Over the next six weeks, the company presents 43 ballets by 22 choreographers, including Justin Peck, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon. Ice baths and massages await. The reason? The Here/Now Festival, which kicks off four weeks of jam-packed programs on Tuesday, April 18. The festival celebrates the 25th anniversary of the company’s New Combinations Fund, which supports new choreography.

2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: In middle age, hip-hop has embraced nostalgia with ferocity. It is the soundtrack of several generations of young people now, some of whom are old enough to be wistful about how it used to be. For them, there’s comfort in reunion shows — last year, it was Bad Boy Records, and this year, it’s Ruff Ryders, the Yonkers crew that kept 1990s New York rap grounded in the streets while others flirted with pop.

2017-04-12.snippet: A CNN documentary series examines the interrelationship of music and civil rights, 9/11, Vietnam, the women’s movement and more.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Music perhaps isn’t the first thing that comes to mind when you think about the most traumatic or galvanizing events of modern times. An image or an influential person probably is. But over time, such events become imbued with music, a phenomenon explored in “Soundtracks: Songs That Defined History,” an eight-part documentary series that begins Thursday, April 20, on CNN.
2017-04-12.headline_main: ‘Soundtracks’ on CNN: The Songs of History’s Most Significant Moments

2017-04-12.abstract: This elusive German soprano will be accompanied by the eloquent pianist Malcolm Martineau.
2017-04-12.snippet: This elusive German soprano will be accompanied by the eloquent pianist Malcolm Martineau.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: A wonderfully old-fashioned, fainting-couch glamour clings to the Lieder interpretations by the soprano Anne Schwanewilms. A star on opera stages in her native Germany, she has made herself all too rare in New York since her brilliant 2013 debut in the Metropolitan Opera’s “Die Frau Ohne Schatten.” Her recording of songs by Schumann and Wolf is imbued with a languid sensuality that evokes an earlier, less hurried age. On Sunday, April 16, accompanied by the eloquent pianist Malcolm Martineau, she appears at Alice Tully Hall, performing selections by Wolf and Strauss that are set to showcase her opulent, dusky tone and her obsessive attention to diction, down to vowels that she can brighten or cloud over at will to match the emotion of the text. (Alice Tully Hall, 212-721-6500; lcgreatperformers.org.)
2017-04-12.headline_main: Anne Schwanewilms Performs Wolf and Strauss at Lincoln Center

2017-04-12.snippet: The program, “Making Faces on Film,” kicks off with a 1925 film by Oscar Micheaux featuring Paul Robeson in two roles.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: The road to authentic black representation in cinema, in front of the camera and behind it, has been long and tortuous. “Making Faces on Film: A Collaboration with BFI Black Star,” a program at the Museum of Modern Art (in tandem with the British Film Institute) starting Tuesday, April 18, traces that evolution from diffuse perspectives.

2017-04-12.abstract: This Pulitzer-winning playwright finally gets her due, with a retelling of a controversial 1923 play that featured Broadway’s first stage kiss between two women.
2017-04-12.snippet: This Pulitzer-winning playwright finally gets her due, with a retelling of a controversial 1923 play that featured Broadway’s first stage kiss between two women.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: For a longish stretch, fans of the Pulitzer-winning playwright Paula Vogel had cause for selfish worry. Season after season in the American theater brought plays by the extraordinary talents she nurtured as a teacher, first at Brown and later at Yale — Lynn Nottage, Sarah Ruhl, Martyna Majok, and the list goes on. But Ms. Vogel’s new work was scarce, seemingly back-burnered by her devotion to younger generations.

2017-04-12.abstract: Two mathematical models converge to illuminate the process through which an ocellated lizard’s scales repeatedly change color.
2017-04-12.snippet: Two mathematical models converge to illuminate the process through which an ocellated lizard’s scales repeatedly change color.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: The ocellated lizard — known as the jeweled lacerta in the pet trade — is born rusty brown with white polka dots. Within a few months, its skin begins to change into a dizzying, labyrinthine array of black and bright green pixels. By the time the lizard has sexually matured, reaching up to two feet in length, some 4,000 scales along its back are all black or green, possibly to accommodate a habitat change between early life and adulthood. Through the rest of the lizard’s life, many of these scales will continually flip between black and green.
2017-04-12.headline_main: A Lizard With Scales That Behave Like a Computer Simulation

2017-04-12.abstract: Here, the young women behind each site tell us what they’re feeling for spring.
2017-04-12.snippet: Here, the young women behind each site tell us what they’re feeling for spring.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Introducing three new names you will want to add to your bookmark bar. These indie e-boutiques, based in California, are earning a reputation as indispensable resources for building a wardrobe. Minimalists will want to stock up at the Dreslyn, a Los Angeles site that specializes in elevated basics, while quirky cool girls will fall for the approachable, on-trend styles at Lisa Says Gah, based in San Francisco. Shop Super Street, which has a brick-and-mortar store in Los Angeles, works a high-low mix, with newbie designers sharing space alongside established brands like Isabel Marant and the street wear labels Huf and Alyx. Wrapped in a visually appealing, Instagram-friendly package, the shops are an antidote to the feeling of sameness that can sneak up on us as we browse down the endless scroll at e-commerce giants. And whether or not you make the click to buy, the on-point styling and roster of under-the-radar labels all but guarantee you’ll close the tab a little more inspired than before.
2017-04-12.headline_main: 3 Cool E-Boutique Owners on What to Buy Now

A cluster of twirling couples danced to a cumbia beat under the low-slung ceiling, while onlookers clutched bottles of Victoria beer. Some slipped notes to the D.J. scribbled on napkins, but they weren’t requests.

2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: From the beginning, the Chainsmokers knew dance music was a joke. The festivals, the groupthink, the blunt-force sounds — these were the hallmarks of a scene designed for ecstatic release, but also one that was easily parodied.

2017-04-12.abstract: The company’s debut season in New York, at the Joyce Theater, includes an unusual dance — to Dylan Thomas poems read by the actor Richard Burton.
2017-04-12.snippet: The company’s debut season in New York, at the Joyce Theater, includes an unusual dance — to Dylan Thomas poems read by the actor Richard Burton.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: If you measure a line of verse in terms of feet, you’re recognizing its inner dance impulse. The links between poetry and dance go back several millenniums — but usually they’re made by music. With Christopher Bruce’s “Ten Poems,” however, the only music is the spoken word: recordings by the actor Richard Burton of poems by his fellow Welshman Dylan Thomas. Though not unprecedented, this is so unusual that it comes as a blast of fresh air.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Review: Scottish Ballet Finds the Poetry in ... Poetry

2017-04-12.abstract: Each installment of “Fast and Furious” is more enjoyably ludicrous than the last, even as the death of the star Paul Walker continues to hang over the franchise.
2017-04-12.snippet: Each installment of “Fast and Furious” is more enjoyably ludicrous than the last, even as the death of the star Paul Walker continues to hang over the franchise.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: One of the givens of “Fast and Furious” is that the latest movie will be bigger and more enjoyably ludicrous than the last. The miniskirts will be shorter, the toys zoomier, the stunts more delirious. Yet, like every successful series, this one delivers its sleek new bits and pieces in reassuringly familiar packaging. James Bond has queen and country. Vin Diesel’s Dominic Toretto — the monotonal “Fast and Furious” paterfamilias — has cars and camaraderie, an ideal combo for movies about American outsiders whose home has always been one another.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Review: Family Values and Hot Rides in ‘Fate of the Furious’

2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: With a title like “Cuisine & Confessions,” you’d be forgiven for thinking that this production at the Skirball Center was a satire of our culture’s twin obsessions with food and oversharing — the first show about Instagram, maybe? But a more accurate, albeit more cumbersome, designation would be “Cuisine & Confessions & Flashy Stunts That Will Make You Gasp.” That’s a lot to handle, but Les 7 Doigts de la Main (the 7 Fingers) is used to juggling.

2017-04-12.abstract: The Schomburg Center in Harlem has bought this author’s rich archive. But the private letters admirers have longed to read will largely remain under seal.
2017-04-12.snippet: The Schomburg Center in Harlem has bought this author’s rich archive. But the private letters admirers have longed to read will largely remain under seal.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: James Baldwin died in 1987, but his moment is now. His books are flying off the shelves. He has inspired homages like Raoul Peck’s documentary “I Am Not Your Negro” and Ta-Nehisi Coates’s memoir “Between the World and Me.” Baldwin’s prophetic essays on race read like today’s news.
2017-04-12.headline_main: James Baldwin’s Archive, Long Hidden, Comes (Mostly) Into View

2017-04-12.abstract: In “Fallen Glory,” James Crawford provides a tour from the Tower of Babel to the World Trade Center.
2017-04-12.snippet: In “Fallen Glory,” James Crawford provides a tour from the Tower of Babel to the World Trade Center.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: “In its lifetime, the same building can meet Julius Caesar, Napoleon and Adolf Hitler,” James Crawford writes in “Fallen Glory: The Lives and Deaths of History’s Greatest Buildings.” “What human could claim the same?” Crawford’s book tells the stories of 21 great and influential sites — their conception, construction and destruction — from the Tower of Babel to the Bastille to the World Trade Center. In doing so, he tours much of world history, and attempts to look into the future as well. Below, Crawford tells us about the inspiration for the book, what he learned while writing it and more.
2017-04-12.headline_main: Tell Us 5 Things About Your Book: 21 Great Buildings Throughout History

2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United States ambassador to the United Nations, Nikki R. Haley, signaled on Wednesday morning that the Trump administration wanted to work with Russia to end the war in Syria. A few hours later, Ms. Haley drew a line in the diplomatic sand, forcing Russia to use its veto for an eighth time on a Syria resolution in the United Nations Security Council.

2017-04-12.abstract: The features of 245-million-year-old Teleocrater fossils may help fill in our understanding of how dinosaurs evolved.
2017-04-12.snippet: The features of 245-million-year-old Teleocrater fossils may help fill in our understanding of how dinosaurs evolved.
2017-04-12.lead_paragraph: Paleontologists excavating a basin in southern Tanzania have uncovered 245-million-year-old fossils belonging to one of the earliest relatives of dinosaurs. The carnivorous creature, which is not a direct ancestor to dinosaurs but more of a close cousin, is called Teleocrater rhadinus. The discovery, which was reported Wednesday in Nature, may help scientists fill in gaps in our understanding of how dinosaurs evolved as well as provide insight into what their earliest relatives looked like.
2017-04-12.headline_main: A Dinosaur Cousin’s Crocodile Ankles Surprise Paleontologists

2017-04-13.abstract: The decline was too precipitous to be Alzheimer’s. What was it?
2017-04-13.snippet: The decline was too precipitous to be Alzheimer’s. What was it?
2017-04-13.lead_paragraph: “I feel very pain,” the 62-year-old mumbled incoherently as he sat in a wheelchair. He had said almost nothing since arriving at the office of Dr. Joel Geerling, a neurologist at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. A year ago, he was fine, explained the patient’s sister. He was married, working as an auto mechanic, happy, normal. Then, six or seven months ago, he became forgetful. Little things at first — he couldn’t think of the right word, remember people’s names. But then big things — like forgetting who he was talking to on the phone or how to drive to places he had known for decades.
2017-04-13.headline_main: Why Did This Man Lose His Memory, Words and Even His Ability to Walk?

2017-04-13.abstract: From “Idiocracy” to “Silicon Valley,” the writer and director has established himself as America’s foremost chronicler of its own self-destructive tendencies.
2017-04-13.snippet: From “Idiocracy” to “Silicon Valley,” the writer and director has established himself as America’s foremost chronicler of its own self-destructive tendencies.
2017-04-13.lead_paragraph: As we took a seat in the back of the Commissary, a restaurant on the Sony Pictures Studios lot, Mike Judge pointed out a man seated two booths away. It was Tom Rothman, the chairman of Sony Pictures and former head of Fox’s film division, where he oversaw the rocky release of Judge’s 2006 film, “Idiocracy.” The movie imagined America 500 years in the future, populated and ruled by absolute morons, its infrastructure crumbling, its cities piled high with trash, everyone anesthetized by impossibly stupid television like the hit show “Ow! My Balls!” Though the film finished shooting in 2004, the studio mothballed it for more than a year. When “Idiocracy” was finally released, it wasn’t screened for critics or promoted in any other way — there wasn’t even a trailer — and it was shown in only seven cities, New York not among them. The studio, it seemed, was fulfilling the bare minimum of its contractual obligations, as if hoping that the movie would just go away.
2017-04-13.headline_main: Mike Judge, the Bard of Suck

2017-04-13.snippet: ‘Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer,’ Joseph Cedar’s latest film, pits Jew against Jew on the fringes of power and influence.
2017-04-13.lead_paragraph: The full, spoilerish title of Joseph Cedar’s new movie — “Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer” — is more or less literally accurate, though it might be argued that “fixer” is a bit euphemistic, if not downright fantastical. In his own mind, Norman Oppenheimer, a well-dressed, well-spoken Manhattanite played with feeling and mischief by Richard Gere, is what’s known in Yiddish as a macher. He travels the circuits of money and influence, always just a few capillaries removed from the beating heart of power. His mental Rolodex swells with the names of the good and the great, every one of them “a very close friend.” He’d be happy to introduce you.
2017-04-13.headline_main: Review: Richard Gere as ‘Norman,’ an Aspirational Fixer

2017-04-13.lead_paragraph: In Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Adam Kirsch and Liesl Schillinger discuss the art yielded by populist and elite mind-sets.
2017-04-13.headline_main: Which Force is More Harmful to the Arts: Elitism or Populism?

2017-04-13.abstract: For dying patients, a new book argues that palliative care methods are often better than the typical intensive care unit approach.
2017-04-13.snippet: For dying patients, a new book argues that palliative care methods are often better than the typical intensive care unit approach.
2017-04-13.lead_paragraph: While confronting the prospect of death, people like me — grappling with a diagnosis of advanced cancer — often consider what sort of care they want and how to say goodbye. Given the delicate negotiations in which the dying need to engage, do intensive care physicians with their draconian interventions act like proverbial bulls in a china shop? My fear of pointless end-of-life treatments, performed while I was in no condition to reject them, escalated when I read Dr. Jessica Nutik Zitter’s book, “Extreme Measures: Finding a Better Path to the End of Life.”
2017-04-13.headline_main: At the End of Life, a Way to Go Gentle
